column4: Hi!  Is anyone here running Ubuntu 9.04?  I would like some help.
the best way to create a menu.lst in ubuntu is to have the system do it. Move the one in /boot/grub/ out of the way (rename, move) then run  sudo update-grub
try chrooting into the install from another (the live cd, for example) then running the update-grub command
Oh, will "sudo update-grub" do it if grub has never been installed in the first place?  I will try that.  Ok to do from live Ubuntu CD, right?
be sure to chroot
There *is* no install to chroot into; installation didn't complete.  (Well, I guess technically it did.)

you may need to install grub from inside the install.  chroot is your friend while repairing the system. If the install didn't complete (and grub is the only thing that failed) just installing grub should do it
Okay... I'll need pointers on how to chroot.  I'm going to read the man page.
sudo blkid  in the 8.04 will show you the uuid of the partion
I'm installing 9.04 on a desktop; I'm just using the 8.04 on my laptop as a reference because I don't have a working 9.04 system to compare to.
ah. well, you can still do it from the live cd
Okay, so I would do 'chroot /path/to/rootdir_of_harddrive grub-update'?
that's part of it. There's some prep work; a sec while I find a reference
Sorry, that should be 'chroot /path/to/rootdir_of_harddrive sudo update-grub'
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/RecoveringUbuntuAfterInstallingWindows?action=show&redirect=RestoreGrub#Preparing%20Your%20Working%20Environment has the steps to get a proper chroot env
Wow, this is great!  I'll try it.  I'll probably be away for a bit.
good luck I'm hoping that grub is your only issue ;)
I hope it's the only issue, too.  I can't believe we're at v9.04 and it still can't install itself properly.  Maybe it's SATA that it's having trouble with, or the very large size of the drive.
I've had problems with mixed sata/pata systems, but otherwise it's installed well
what was it?
I put my main partition at the end of my 1.5TB drive.  On manually using grub, it complained that the cylinder was too far out for BIOS to handle.
so I just put the main partition at the beginning of the drive, and everything went smoothly.
It would be nice for the installer to pass on these messages so I don'
don't have to guess at what the problem was.  Geez, man!
